As a proud, sad, passionate and dedicated lifetime Baltimorean all I can say is Yes!!!  Thanks for telling our story.  Not stories, STORY, because we are all really connected like that... "Smalltimore"  It makes me feel so whole to see our reality played out with such complexity and honor for who we are, who we try to be and who we end up being in the end.  My boys and I say thanks WIRE for helping us tell the world what we are made of and why we love our town in spite of it all!

So you thought they would clear up everything and everybody would live happily everafter? Well, life ain't no fairytale. Things were left off just as I expected. Just one tidbit, Daniels could never try a case in front of that particular judge, could he? Wouldn't that be conflict of interest. Still, as in life, the more things change the more they stay the same. Somebody always moves into somebody elses place. So the players play on in this game. Thank you fellas. Thank you writers. Thank you actors. And thank you crew members for an excellent five years. If you do a movie, I'll be there. If this is all there is, I thank you. It was enough. You didn't overstay your welcome. It's just a shame enough people didn't pick up on how good this series was until it was almost over. Bunk you were truly 'murder police.' Dukey my heart goes out to you. Omar, who woulda thought tears could almost be shed over the loss of a gay, Black stickup man. Marlowe, you will always be the gangsta everybody loves to hate. Who needs Scarface, we've got Marlowe. Chris, baddest, coldest killa in the game. Snoop, you still look good, Girl. Michael, you did what you had to do. I respect you for that. You understand the code. Lester Freeman, you are the best at what you do. And, that is anything you decide to do. Clay Davis, my man. (nuff said). Bubs, they faded you out but, hey, why shouldn't you get a chance to chill and stop chasin'. Keema, you are police with a conscience. That's cool. Carchetti, you are a snake. Talk good game, but in the long run, you're just an opportunist. I guess that's how you move on up. 'The Wire,' I'll be talking about it for a mighty long time.

The Wire (2002-2008) is excellent. It paved the way for an even better drug crime show, Breaking Bad (2008-2013).

Most people are aware of corporate espionage and what some companies will do to protect their secrets. In the TV show Breaking Bad the two main characters, Walter White, played by Bryan Cranston, and Jesse Pinkman, played by Aaron Paul, possess the knowledge and skill to produce the best meth on the market. And their brand is easily identifiable by its unique blue color.

Several competing criminal organizations buy their services and try to replicate their product but Whites and Pinkmans skill in the art and science of making their blue meth product isn't easily duplicated. One group tries to hold Pinkman hostage in Mexico because their highly trained scientists cant make meth as well as he does. Near the end of the series another criminal group keeps Pinkman chained in their lab and force him to make meth for them because their guy, who worked with both White and Pinkman, is unable to duplicate Pinkmans and Walter Whites skill in the art and science of making their blue meth brand.

Breaking Bad has one of the best story and character arcs ever used in a TV show, which is why it has an IMDb rating of 9.5, right up there with Game of Thrones, another great show. The Wire (2002-2008) was as good as the Sons of Anarchy (2008-2014), but not as good as Breaking Bad. I won't give away the ending of Breaking Bad, but if you watch the complete series, from the first episode to the last, the ending will make complete sense and be very satisfying. Its terrific.

If the above series don't sound interesting here are a few of the series I really enjoyed watching more than once: Band of Brothers (2001), Battlestar Galactica (2004-2009), Black Sails (2014-2017), Cowboy Bebop (1998), Downton Abbey (2010-2015), Firefly (2002), Game of Thrones (2011-2019), The IT Crowd (2006-2013), Jericho (2006-2008), Lonesome Dove (1989), Lost (2004-2010), Merlin (2008-2012), Pride and Prejudice (1995), Rome (2005-2007), Spartacus: Gods of the Arena (2011), Stargate: SG-1 (1997-2007), Stargate: Atlantis (2004-2009), Star Trek The Original Series (1966-1969) and Star Trek Voyager (1995-2001). I didn't list any contemporary series Im following that don't have an end date yet, not conducive to binge watching from beginning to finish, or the hundreds of other fantasy and science fiction shows Ive watched.

If you like reading try some of my favorite authors: Richard Adams, Palo Bacigulupi, Suzanne Collins, Abe Evergreen, Diana Gabaldon, Hugh Howey, George Martin, Brandon Sanderson, John Scalzi, and Andy Weir.

Wow! I've seen a lot of great series on television and this is by far, one of the best! The characters, the storyline and the way everything was portrayed, simply AMAZING! I love how the producers tied everything together and really tell the story of most big cities in America, from the drug dealers and "hoppers" to the police and it's chain of command; they even tied in politics, showing how dirty some will get to get where/what they want. I especially liked the last season, as they did a great job at bringing everything home and leaving all the characters on fairly good terms with the audience. I'm glad we got to see "bubbs" make it through his addiction and begin to lead a life of recuperation and happiness; in the same breath, I'm disappointed that "dukie" has taken an inevitable turn for the worse into drugs. Although in the beginning McNulty wasn't too pleasing of a character, by this last season I definitely took a liking to him. Because of his boldness and courage, along with Detective Freamon, they were able to take down Marlo and his crew and account for most of the crime and drug trafficking occurring in the neighborhood. I loved almost all the characters, however, my absolute favorite was Omar because of his wittiness and old school charisma. While most of his actions were downright despicable, you can't help but to think there's a lot of good in him. With that being said, it hurt me to my core to see him killed in S5, especially in the way in which it was done; if anything, that would be my only criticism. Overall, the director and producers did a damn good job with this series, kudos!

The Wire never won an Emmy. That's the real crime. Like all his work, David Simon outdid himself with The Wire. Treme is actually my favorite of his shows (you should absolutely watch it, it never got enough attention while it was airing), but there will never be another show as good as The Wire. Part of this is also attributable to the perfect casting (many of the actors aren't American, but you would never know). I love that each season was a new case, but that the thread of Baltimore crime wove them all together. Some day it will be recognized as the groundbreaking show that it was.

The Wire is a gritty and gripping detective drama, which is widely considered to be one of the all-time best shows in this genre, as well as being one of the greatest television programs ever made. It was created and primarily written by David Simon, the renowned author and former crime reporter, who, because of his background, was able to impart an uncanny sense of realism to the series. The Wire was set and produced in Baltimore, Maryland, and its story line centers around the organization and function of the criminal drug trade in Baltimore, and the tragic way in which it has ravaged the city, and its beleaguered residents. The Wire consists of a total of sixty episodes, spanning five seasons, with a different emphasis for each season. Although the multifaceted drug trade represents the overarching focus of this series, each individual season assesses the manner in which this criminal enterprise impacts a specific operational area of the city of Baltimore. The first season of The Wire examines the drug trade itself, the second season deals with the dysfunctional seaport system, the third season analyzes the corrupt city government and bureaucracy, the fourth season addresses the deteriorating school system, and the fifth and final season evaluates the unethical print news media. It brutally and realistically depicts the devastating effects that the criminal narcotic trade has had on the residents of inner city Baltimore, whose lives have been destroyed by the pervasive drug-related misery, despair, and hopelessness, which have now become endemic in this population. The Wire is characterized by insightful and brilliant writing, superb plot and character development, and absolutely spectacular acting performances, by its exceedingly talented ensemble cast. It definitely deserves the numerous awards and accolades which it has received over its five-year run. The Wire is a truly outstanding television series, which is riveting, moving, and emotional, and it merits an unequivocal five-star rating, along with a very strong recommendation.

The 5th and final season of The Wire wraps up the storylines of the previous seasons, not into a bow tie present (because a 'perfect', happy ending wouldn't be consistent with the show's history and overall tone), but in a satisfyingly disturbing way.  Lauded as the most 'realistic' crime drama, I will say it is one of the best.  I've seen SouthLAnd, The Shield, Low Winter Sun, Hannibal, Breaking Bad, Sons of Anarchy, Dexter and the likes, and this is arguably in the top 3, with SOA & Dexter at the bottom and The Shield, Breaking Bad & The Wire fighting for the top contender.

It's a shame that the final season of this show only had 10 episodes, compared the last few seasons that got 12 or 13.  Because of this, it goes by a little quicker and it feels like there could've been at least 2 more episodes to show the repercussions of the actions in the final season, as well as give more characters a send off; however, some characters to pop up from previous seasons to show us where they've been or what happened to them.

One thing's for sure, this gritty crime drama pulls no punches, shows the most realistic, fake take on police, politics, the media, gangs, the public schools and the street life out there.  There is a liberal slant to the perspective, but it is very realistic nonetheless, and the raw emotion in the life-like appearance, character and power in the stories will resonate with anyone tied to law enforcement, criminal justice, EMS, urban life, or government sector.  As a police-affiliated worker, I can see a lot of the realities from this show in the real life individuals I interact with while at work. The Wire's not perfect, but it's close.  Many will say this or Breaking Bad are the best of the best. Watch the Wire, and you win either way.  Play with your life in the streets, and you lose either way: that's what The Wire teaches us.

***DVD note***

The version I got IS NOT the slim line, newer 2015 version that is described in the product description.  The other Wire seasons that I purchased through Amazon were all the newer, slim case versions of the dvds just as described, but not this one for some reason.

2004-2008 the David Simon, and Ed Burns returned to Baltimore, and produced this show to speak to the dysfunction in our cities.  The Wire depicts the complex interaction of heroin, broken families, street survival, lazy-ass police, money laundering, and the tribal politics that feeds-on and protects all of the above.  At the bottom, the street is a perpetual war, kids are soldiers, death comes quick, almost as a favor.  Look hard Humanists - human beings are fallen creatures, everybody, we'd rather screw, get high and kill than improve ourselves or our lot.  Only God has the answer to this.  America was built on His principles, it never worked entirely, mankind is incapable of following His plan, but the attempt was better than this.  Don't lie, respect your neighbor's property, respect life, respect your spouse, respect authority, let love into your heart, love God, and know there is only one God, and he is not that pile of cash, power, or the sex-object or substance that gets you off.

I loved the authenticity of the story. For years I worked in Philadelphia's worst areas for drugs, murder, and crime, and The Wire depicts an accurate description of the absolute cold-hearted, sociopathic ways of the streets.  People getting killed just on suspicion of something they "might have said," or because the money or drug count was short.  It's a nasty, cruel way to live, but for so many, this is all they know. Children suffer greatly. Education suffers- police are corrupt, higher up officials are corrupt.  Money disappears into the government's deep pockets.  Families are torn apart and every community is affected.  It is like a pebble dropped in water. The poison all spreads out from the unfortunate losers who are the pebble, and who have so much power and street smarts that their layers may go so deep that their dirt may never be swept off the streets and it just keeps piling up. It becomes overwhelming at best.  If you want a realistic, well written, and superbly acted  police story- this is it. I laughed and I cried as I watched The Wire- I was disgusted and saddened at times, but cracking up at the humor and lifted up as well.  Loved it- just wish there were more of it!!
By Far Best Series Ever
Hands down, the best season of any show of all time.
The great

Living in the Baltimore metro area and following the news - the Wire gives an excellent insight as to why the drug trade is prevalent and deadly in Baltimore city. The lawyers, police and politicians are all part of the problem along with the crushing poverty in the inner city, the bad schools, fatherless homes thanks to the government handouts of EBT cards, welfare, section 8 housing vouchers and healthcare keeps the women in the community dependent on the government. It's as if they're married to the government. In several episodes the series showed how they're not very parents and the system lets them get away with childish behavior even though it detrimental to the emotional and physical development of their kids.

Watching the wire and from my own observations and experience over the past 40 years I can now better understand how so many black youths end up in the drug trade and how hard it is for them to escape the environment they were born in.

Compelling storyline and so what's happening in our inner cities today.  This story tackled backroom deals in politics and the police force, how the good cops had to go through changes and deals to get their job done while the bad cops just do what they always do take advantage of their positions so they can move up the ladder  Drug dealing and how even little kids get caught up in the mess all for the sake of getting money...lack of parenting responsibilities..education of street & problem kids ..just pass them along to get them out of those teachers classes to the next ...corruption of longshore men getting involved with hoodlums for stolen goods, transporting foreign women for sex trade and even how high paid lawyers get drug dealers out from serving time...and more...One of the best if not the best urban series.

I'm sure I watched at least some of the series when it originally aired as I could remember bits and pieces of different episodes. My wife and I watched all 5 seasons during the last two months. We'd try and catch one or two episodes each night when we were free for TV watching. The first couple of seasons were outstanding. A cop friend from that area said the episodes were as close as you can get to the real thing. The street culture of the ghetto (if it is politically correct to use the term) was rather shocking to those of us who have led a sheltered life. Its easy to see why very few young people escape to a better life. The last 3 seasons were good. It was interesting to follow the various characters. Now too many of the residents made it alive to the end of the series. The value of life to these gangsters is shocking. It is easy to see why the carnage in Chicago is at the level it is this year. And in the end at the close of season 5 life on the street was the same as when the show started on season 1. Only the characters changed.

Although Season Two, for me, still has the greatest resonance of all the years of the series, Season Five towers above almost all other tv shows. Season Five's additional focus, with governmental corruption and inefficiencies and, of course the drug trade, is on print journalism. At the time the season was filmed, print journalism hadn't yet entered the degree of the death spiral it's in now. The story line does include the declining fortunes of the Baltimore paper it focuses on. A central focus, ripped from headlines of that era, is on a reporter who fabricates the crux of his stories. A particularly inventive subplot - hats off to all of those at the writers table - has McNulty creating a fictitious series of serial murders. He does so in order to use some of the extra man hours allotted to the search for the nonexistent killer in his effort to bring down drug kingpin Marlo Stanfield. As with every season of this show, volumes could be written about all the plot elements and their links to actual events and the continuing tragedies that befall not only Baltimore but many of our inner cities. It's such a pleasure when that occasional show that examines the current state of the country succeeds.

Is this review even necessary? I suppose so, since everyones tastes are different. That said, in MY opinion(which is my own), The Wires the best tv show ever produced. Several others have come close, but this is, for me, as good as it gets. That said, season 5 to me is the 'weakest' of the 5 seasons and I'm giving it 5 stars. That's saying something. This show not just excellent, its CONSISTENTLY excellent. I did not watch this when it first came out. Hell I hadnt even HEARD of it when it first came out (probably because I didn't have HBO at the time).

When I found it? My entire extended weekend was spent watching. And I'm not a binge watcher by nature. I just could not get enough. That said, if you're looking at season 5, you've seen the other 4, and there's about 0% chance you will NOT pick up the last season even if I gave it 0 stars. I'd challenge anyone to watch the first 4 seasons and have no interest in seeing how the series ends. Not possible in my opinion.

So, in short(sort of)- get it, watch it, love it, rinse, repeat. Thats not sarcasm- I've watched this entire series probably seven times through and STILL would not be able to pass it up if I saw it on my channel lineup.

It is my view that 'The Wire' is one of the finest series ever produced for television.  It is gutsy, hard-hitting, and more accurate at every level than most would like to admit.  Season 5 is a first rate close to the series.  Good and Evil, the Merely Bad and the Dishonest flourish with aplomb.  The characters, even some of the truly evil ones, are extremely well drawn and in their own twisted way, sympathetic.  I have never seen a series that mirrored real life and a specific city so accurately....as recent history has proven.

I've hear for years that the show was really good! I decided to see what the hoopla was all about. I was in awe. This show was raw, gritty, real, gut and heart wrenching. Beautifully done! I could go on and on. At the end I was so disappointed to find out there was only 5 seasons! I binged watched this powerful series clenching my teeth, as my favorite characters fell..... There aren't any shows that come close th this powerful, edge of your seat drama. I will always remember the characters. The Barksdales, Marlow... McNutty (McNutty). Lol! I rarely root for the under dog..... But I better... Omar comin y'all! Hey! Omar comin everybody! Omar comin'! Love it! Omar brought the danger to the hood... He was a Viking! A rebel. True to himself, compassionate... But grimey , ruthless, and cold. This show has been one of the best shows that I've never watched!

This show uses a lot of police jargon, street slang, and court room and does not explain it so you have to use context clues or look it up to completely understand. The 5th season started slow to me but then it got really good then it became amazing. This is a very well though out story and is a true work of art. You really need to pay attention to when they talk because things will happen off camera and will not make any sense if you do not remember what they were talking about earlier. The character development is very realistic and impressive. Some part were very boring to me, but as the show went on, I became more invested in the dialogue and the frequency at which I was bored decreased. The best part of this series in my opinion are the characters. You may grow to love and hate some of them. Even when you do not agree with them, you kind of hope things end up okay for them. If you like crime dramas in general, then this series is for you.

The entire series is fantastic but the opening part of season 5 is perhaps the best acting that I've ever seen in my life. Having work for a police department when I was younger it's very easy to assume that some of these young kids are just that stupid and are the victims of their own ignorance when dealing with the police and criminal situations. Everyone that I talk to you comes from the Baltimore area always tell similar stories that are expressed in the episode on The Wire. This is one show where you binge watch all 5 Seasons and it's like watching a Masterpiece Theater. The writing is simply brilliant and is able to capture the urban flavor of Baltimore perfectly. The only negative thing I can say is that there's only 5 Seasons and not more. But all good things must come to an end and this definitely is a good thing.

The Baltimore Police Department is giving it their best effort, but is it enough.  Crocked politicians and unethical lawyers add to the mix.

After many decades, I have never come close to watching an entire TV series, except and until I watched this one.  In literature circles, they used to say there were the Dostoevsky people and the Tolstoy people.  This one was definitely for the Dostoevsky people.  The terrible, the beautiful, and the funny, all tied into one.

While the series did "juke the stats" occasionally for pleasing a wider contemporary audience, this is not a serious criticism -  it has never stopped art from becoming timeless.  I predict this one ages well.

This series built up to a giant let down.  Lots of promising character development and increasingly complex story lines lead to a final season of killing off the series's best character with no explanation, a boring side story of a dysfunctional newspaper, and a department cover up so unrealistic it's comical.

Each of the others seasons had well thought out plot lines and outstanding character arcs.  The police procedural was woven nicely into the story of Baltimore and each finale neatly wrapped everything up without rushing the narrative.  Not with this season...within the premier episode alone an entire story line is completely wiped out with no explanation, and the series ends with a very corny full circle mantra about how nothing ever really changes, having characters with very compelling narratives simply filling the shoes of characters from previous seasons.  Nothing is wrapped up, and at the same time nothing is left to the imagination.  The best characters in the series are either killed off or written out abruptly, and the season comes to an end with a friend's betraying McNulty's lie just shrugged off like it was no big deal.  Who wrote this garbage?  The newspaper side story as a parallel of the department was a snooze fest, and there was absolutely no reason to invest in any of the characters there, save for Gus, which was simply a placeholder instead of a dynamic piece of the story line.

I don't get into many TV series, but I was really enjoying this one...that is until season 5.  This was, without doubt, the worst series ender I have ever watched.  If everything was going to just the same as when the series began, then why watch anything at all?  Why introduce the notion that Leavy could finally burn like the scum he is only to turn the final showdown between him and Ronnie into a draw?  And what of Herc?  He becomes nothing but a sidekick to Leavy.....for what?  He nearly served no purpose except to advance a forced exposition.  Nothing in this series makes any sense.  Colvin had the chance to take a pop shot at the mayor....but nothing happens.  Why set any of this up if it was all just impotent?  This season had absolutely no point, other than to mark a official end to the series.

In this season, The Wire brings together its loose ends including the outcome of McNulty's unraveling. The fact that David Simon focuses on the plight of the newspaper industry, which has gotten much worse since Season Five's original airing, brings the story full circle. In addition, pay special attention to reporter Scott Templeton, viewers may think he is a farcical character, but he is not. As a former newspaper reporter, I worked with an editor with his kind of ethics. Once again, The Wire delivers. It is arguably the greatest television series of all time.

As addicting as the first four seasons. As things change, the more they stay the same. Corruption abounds. McNulty takes his latest and last dive off the deep end. Marlo is back and as dangerous as ever. The newspaper angle and the newsroom characters, lead by Clark Johnson, are as entertaining as the police characters. Irony abounds. It's hard not to root for even some of the bad guys - Omar, Proposition Joe, and Michael. Possibly the most well-written show ever on TV.  Enjoy Baltimore one crazy day at a time.

Went on a binge with The Wire as I had not seen it in a long time and I'm not sure if I ever saw season 5.  McNulty has gone far over even his shady edge when he concocts a serial killer so that the mayor, Carcetti, desperate for some positive press, will funnel money to the police. Some of this money goes to Freaman in his on-going attempt to bring in Marlo. This season focuses on the roll of the press in helping McNulty pull off his scheme so there's a cast of half dozen reporters for The Sun.  So the typical triangle between police--city hall--and this time the press continues.  This is the last season, however, so there is a sense that the characters are taking their last laps as we see many who have become so familiar continue to develop--the end provides a very satisfying review of what seems to be going to happen to them now that we can't watch anymore.  A very satisfying conclusion to a great show.

So I suggest that maybe, just maybe you should just WATCH YOUR LANGUAGE. I mean, what is it with that word that it has to be repeated over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over again and again and again and again...How many times have you used "please" and "thank-you" and "God bless you" in a day, a week, in a year? I think this would be a great show...but, truly, I don't need that "F" word the way some of you do. So, I guess I will miss out. BTW, just funnin' you on the five stars...for the language it is a minus, minus, minus 100,000 stars and more.

Because of the depth of subject and how well it was presented I again give the wire 5 stars.  I must warn that it is extremely vulgar and racist because the content requires it to be so.  Adults who want an inside look at gang politics, police and govt politics and how the 2 clash each day should see this series.  Although without giving too much up about the final season, it does try to bring closure to some of the issues from the first 4 seasons.  However I don't know how one can leave the series without the feeling that cities just will not be able to find a solution to the violence and death within the gang society. Sure I can say without a doubt that the destruction of the family structure..... easy divorce....lack of work income,... poor education by the school system .. DRUGS and DRUG MONEY.contribute to the on going structure survival and that structure is so strong it seems impossible for govt and authority to break.  This series will affect how you view the gangs and kids looking for family.

Very few shows deserve a 5 star rating but "The Wire" comes close. This series is tense, dark, sadly pessimistic, well constructed and edited. It certainly presents a dim view of human beings in the contemporary failing big US city (eg, Chicago, now!). The 5th is a well constructed finale to a brilliant series, but uses a few contrived or exaggerated premises to achieve the less than optimistic conclusion. In this way it is not as successful as the first 4 seasons and almost borders on the frequent manipulation of plot one encounters in the good, but not great films and TV dramas. However, an ending is never easy and this one is more satisfying than most.

I had hoped that The Wire would get back on track after th dismal Season 4, but it wasn't to be.  Season 5 brings back McNulty as a full-blown alcoholic with none of his earlier screen presence, running a scam on "the bosses" with a fake serial killer.  There's a very shallow portrayal of a newsroom, with Omar coming back as some kind of superman.

  All of your favorite characters turn out to be just idols with feet of clay, and the worst characters of the series are allowed to remain around to ruin the credibility of the storylines.  The Wire had just enough juice for the first three seasons.  It would have been a better series had it ended there instead of dragging on for two very poorly done encore seasons.

The whole series provides insight into the entire broken system and how it doesn't work for the people.  The realities of corrupt politicians who never were interested in doing good with their power for the people they represent, the legal system's need to provide conviction numbers at all costs, the educational system trying not only to educate but raise the broken children whose parent (s) doesn't care or doesn't know how to raise children, the intercity drug/gang culture which in some cases, is the only way children have the sense of belonging or being someone important and the bias media who accepts no responsibility for the publishing or broadcasting of news in a sensationalized way leaving out the truth or actual facts of happenings in the communities and country.
This series makes you ponder what can or should be done and where to begin to solve today's societal problems.

In all honesty this has to be one of the best shows ever on television.  The series has had it's ups and it's downs or should I say high points and lows, with the highs being as good as TV has ever been and the lows being really good TV but sub-par for this series.  Season 5 I would put right in the middle.  If you've watched the other 4 seasons you can see the end coming from a mile away when season 5 starts.  And that's probably the only reason I put season 5 in the middle.  I found myself not being enamored with the story line that set up the end of one of my favorite shows of all time.

Collectively this season was another expert and meticulous look at the inner workings of part of Baltimore's fabric.  This time it was the newspaper world.  But this is a look at newspapers like you've never seen on the screen.  You could just feel how real this was.  The characters were expertly written and perfectly portrayed. The issues they faced are real and not exaggerated for effect.

It was a sad moment hitting play on the last episode but all told it wrapped the series in quality fashion.  If you haven't watched this series don't start with season 5, please.  More likely you've watched the first 4 already if you're reading this so here is my ranking off the top of my head.  Season 1, Season 4, Season 5, Season 3 and then Season 2; ranked best to worst.  Like I said this is on The Wire scale, which most tv shows wouldn't even rate on.  Season 3 and 5 could easily be switched here for me.  The recency effect is probably in play.

David Simon gave us the ending we needed, rather than the one we wanted. In an ideal world, every fan-favorite character would've ended up better off and every criminal gotten his or her due, but this is Charm City. Murder police break the rules, politicians cut deals and hustlers dodge bullets or they don't. The added look into the Baltimore Sun started out slow but ultimately paid off. This was a fitting conclusion to what remains, in my mind, the best crime drama of all time.

Disappointing end to the series. Okay, it wasn't much of a surprise that the boys, 2 brothers and Duquon, would come to a bad end. Life goes on in the precinct. without the Major-Colonel, who resigns rather than fake the stats. The Deputy chief gets a cushy job elsewhere. Two weeks and he'd be out drinking and picking up women in bars.

The Wire was a very well written and very well filmed series which I plan to watch (all 5 seasons) once again.  The concept for the series is that it is all connected.  The success of the drug trade is related to how well the police are able to function which is related to priorities and pressures the politicians are exerting and so on.  The episodes do not stand alone like an NCIS or Elementary but rather each one feeds into the next more like a Downton Abbey or 24 except, of course, The Wire is much grittier because much of it takes place in the rougher neighborhoods of Baltimore.  It's a great insight into the inner city challenges faced in all of our larger cities.  You really feel for the people trying to live in those neighborhoods and the people as well as the people who we rely on to make those neighborhoods safer.

I've been binge watching this series since mid December when everything went into reruns and specials. I'm not sure why I didn't watch this show when it originally aired but I've enjoyed all 5 seasons. At the time of this review I'm only half way through season 5 (the final season) so not sure if the ending of the series will be satisfying. Each season the focus of the story changed while remaining true to the first season. So far season 5 seems to be the weakest season which may be why there were no more after season 5. In a nutshell it's a series about drug trafficking in Baltimore along with corrupt politicians and cops and some of the people that wanted to clean it up. Great series and worth watching.

OK just saw all 5 seasons in about 30 days, luckily I can watch a series that way, no commercials, no long term drawn out time frame, I love to watch an entire series, you can call me a monogamous serial-ist. One series at a time, if its a good one, like The Wire, its the only way to go, as far as I am concerned, like learning a language through immersion. I am now immersed and fluent in this series.

I will give it a 98%. For Season 5, for the entire 5 season Series. It wiggles between a 92% and 100% episode to episode, but the overall average is stellar. Why? Because the show is consistently top shelf; consistently lacking in cliches, consistently dealing with moral ambiguity, heroic endeavoring, the counterpoint of local politics, local business, local police procedural, local education, local News reporting and writing, the poor, the rich,the lazy, the ambitious, the honest, the deceitful, the straightforward and the deceptive. The disciplined, the addicted, the gentle and the violent, the powerless and the powerful and the competitions between members of all these existing groups, and between rival groups, and between various aforementioned civic interests. Its about the law, the laws, the judges, organized crime, wiretapping, information gathering, and in fighting and backstabbing, and love,lust and murder, and money. Sounds like a far reaching show? Hell yeah, it is all over the place, but it rings true because it all seems to be about the same thing, everything is the same thing-temptation, greed, ego, honor, protection, teaming up, going rogue. Accountability, and betrayal.

Like a Shakespearean play, it ties together the many sides of the Human Condition in an ironic and artful expose on Human frailties, shortcomings and Heroic stands leading to the saving of people that are loved. I couldn't stop watching it, it moved me viscerally and intellectually and artistically,over and over, scene by scene. For me, it was a tremendous experience and an unforgettable 5 year show, all consumed in 30 days, wow. 98% is perhaps an unfairly low score, but I don't wish to seem blindly exuberant, and so I will leave it that. All performances were tremendous, there isn't a bad actor among the cast. The leading ensemble was superb. Bravo, Bravo, Bravo.

One of the most realistic television programs of all time.  All five seasons are extremely well written, produced and acted.  Each deals with a different aspect of the "drug problem" - from the youths selling on the streets and their hierarchy, the ports of the city and the people involved with  making money bringing the drugs into the city, the classrooms and social environments into which the cities young people are trying to survive and finally the position juggling and back stabbing inside the city's political world.

In this last season we see how the frustrated cops who actually care about change are forced to resort to working around the system, breaking rules and placing themselves and their jobs in jeopardy in order to actually do some good.

Best true crime / police show ever made.  Corrupt bureaucrats, politicians, sleazy developers are at least as bad as the drug dealers.  It feels real on every level. Favorite characters:  Omar Little (Michael Kenneth Williams), Reginald "Bubbles" Cousins (Andre Royo); actually I loved them all, too many to name.  McNulty (Dominic West) was hard to like, manipulative, impulsive and selfish, but very well-acted.  One of his best scenes was when the FBI profiler was describing the (made-up) serial killer in Season 5, and it sounded exactly like McNulty (who made him up to get city money freed up for police overtime for real police work).  McNulty's look - recognizing himself in the description - was priceless.

I simply did not care because it didn't really appear material to the subject of each episode.  I think it was over-done since every episode of this season had one gang killing another gang member.  If the season was intended to send a message of senseless violence, it succeeded.  But after a while, it became routine and loses it's punch.

I absolutely loved this series! I had heard so many reviews on it, some saying it's the best TV show of all times. I don't know if that is true, but I certainly think it's up there. Fantastic season and ending for a terrific show!

For me, The Wire is the best tv show ever. That said,  the first time I watched season 5 I didn't find it as strong as the other seasons. This time, I think it as great as others. The difference is that they were having fun. All The Wire's clich are present and repeated: "It's Baltimore", "Police work" and the corners. Marlo Stanfield going to fight for a corner wearing suit was too much for me the first time, too easy, too clich. But now I think: they were saying goodbye to their characters and having fun! As well as us, "spectators".

The Wire Season 5 is very serviceable entertainment. It fails to live up to previous year (arguably, the greatest year of television in history) and feels like somewhat of a let down in comparison. The storyline of Bunk and Mcnulty feels particularly ridiculous and stretched. However, it is still miles ahead of 95% of the other dramas out there, and deserves a chance simply based upon the successes of the previous seasons.

Amazing story. The first time I've seen anything on screen that feels as deep as a novel. Not as heart-warming and uplifting as The West Wing, but this is better told, more complex, tighter, deeper, grittier, and far more depressing: "Dickensian," the creators might say. I appreciate this series expecting more from me as a viewer  no shots from previous shows to catch me up, and lots of little details that I enjoy because they resonate back through previous shows and previous seasons. I didn't cry along the way, nor was I moved, the way The West Wing affected me  but I cared about these characters, I mourned when bad things happened to them, and I worried for them when it seemed that they would. The world depicted in The Wire feels like the world as it is; The West Wing showed the world as it could be. I feel inspired by Jed Bartlett and his crew, but I believe in McNulty, Omar, and the kingpins and politicians and addicts and cops and lawyers and the rest of the folk that surround them.

Absolutely one of the best shows ever produced.  Great acting, good plots, and a birds eye view into the systems, how they overlap, similarities, and problems each system can cause for the other. In short, impedes progress and ability to do one's job.  Also proves in systems that it's who you know, and how well you "rub elbows" that gets you places.  May not be correct or fair, but that's the way life goes. Was impressed to look at a well organized "system" of drug distribution and dealing, and how sophisticated that system can be!!! Equals or rivals our legal systems!!!!!!  Am so sorry this series ended, but can see interest being lost by most who are looking for gripping stories and not looking at systems.

The Wire may be the best TV series ever.  It tackles the social good and bad of crime, police, journalism, education with a raft of engaging characters, all clearly motivated.  It shows the sickness of the system, and can explain a lot of why problems exist in major US urban areas without taking sides.  It is the Crime and Punishment of its era.

For those of you who haven't lived in Baltimore, this is just great entertainment infused with a little bit "issues of urban blight".  If you live in Baltimore, you just want to cry for the soul of this city.  Listen to the speech Tommy Carcetti gave before the criminal justice committee at the end of Season Three.  Fast forward to April 2015, the Baltimore Riots,  and you can hear it repeat itself over and over again. David Simon is prescient, talented, and insightful.
Baltimore City should employ him as a consultant in their desire to "move forward".

While the first 4 seasons of The Wire were awesome, SEASON FIVE IS SOME OF THE WORST TV EVER.  I cannot believe the outlandish story line and desperate attempts to make the show interesting.  The McNulty fake murderer story is so ridiculous and far fetched, watching it becomes more of a comedy than a serious, hard edged, police procedural that the first 4 seasons were.  Then, there is the Marlo killing everyone with impunity piece that becomes almost like a horror story, so implausible and random.  Worst of all is the journalism angle that focuses sadly on the dumb comedy of errors that develops when one loser journalist starts faking his reporting on the fake murders that are occurring.  The whole thing is a mess and loses the intensity and realism of the first four seasons.  No wonder the show ended after this season.

Serious, impactful, dramatic recreation of today's  inner city life. Accurately reflects our drug culture, the plight of most major cities and the governmental flaws faced by our law enforcement personal. The characters portray frustration, failure, and human flaws with realism and gritty emotion. The story line allows  viewers to associate with all sides of inner city life and the bureaucratic levels of corruption and ineptness in addressing the decline of our society and quality of life. This program does not sugar coat the growing epidemic of unemployment, drug use, and government corruption. It is refreshing and gripping to view "real life" and present truly realistic lifestyles while purposely not glamorizing drugs as so many other programs have done previously.
  Though shocking at times and "in your face" honest, it is worth the watch from the safe confines of your home. It allows the viewer to enter neighborhoods they would never dare venture into and view behind the door activities of our governmental bureaucrats to better understand the inner city life we only usually see on the nightly news.

While I could have watched another 5 seasons, I understand that actors (as well as creators, producers, and writers) need to move on. I don't know if I have the time to see it again, but I know that there were many details, and layers of details, that I must have missed on the second viewing, since I saw so many new things this time around. The recent events in Baltimore and elsewhere, involving the lack of community-based policing, fights for K-12 funding, and reflexive white-cop-on-black-citizen violence, only make this series all the more important. It's great American literature, the equivalent of a classic novel about modern urban life. Season Five played with the adjective "Dickensian," and rightly so: it's an appropriate description of The Wire.

I loved the entire series, and would like to give it 5 stars.  But because it is so hard to follow the speech and the plot at times (even with closed captions) that I deducted the one star.
That said, season 5 was quite interesting as it focused on newspapers and politicians, as well as the police and people living in the bad drug neighborhoods.
Having watched the entire series when I now read the newspapers or listen to news I feel I know the back story, where everyone is trading favors and playing loose with the truth.  Just amazing.  I also have a deeper understanding of the inner cities and the desperation some children (and adults) feel with the dangerous circumstances they must deal with and the lack of real attention from the powers that be.

I was late in watching this series - got the DVD's one at a time and recently started watching - and watching and watching ! It was so engrossing that I literally could not stop watching this incredible, true to life , gut wrenching series .
The writing is top notch , some of the best ever .  The characters are well-sketched and after five seasons you truly feel like you know them well .  The characters are multi-dimensional and it realistically portrays many of the " bad guys" , the gang members and drug dealers as pretty decent people with their own ethical code .Conversely , the cops aka the " good guys " are not all good - some are corrupt and unethical while many are driven  , honest and trying their best to clean up Baltimore - an insurmountable task .  I guess what I mean is that the writing in this show humanizes all the characters and is not stereoptypical at all . Many find Omar, who some may just view as a ruthless killer as one of the favorite characters on the show  - primarily because the characters are " fleshed out " and we come to know them more as just caricatures
 .  This show  is so gritty, raw and real  - it is particularly  relevant today with all the violence in Baltimore , Md .
I am shocked that it did not get the recognition it so well- deserved and only lasted five seasons . The acting is superb , the characters are so real and not just caricatures - you will become invested in their lives as if you know them well ,  believe me .
I only wish they would bring this series back and give it more exposure - I would be the first in line to watch this . I have highly recommened this show to family and friends and they all agree it is one of the ten best they tv series they have ever viewed if not  THE best !

This final season made a good conclusion; too bad that it isn't replayed in real time since everything that's going on in Baltimore today, this is very timely.  The Democratic infra structure and design for black failure is never more clearly displayed both in this media presentation as well as the real world.  It's amazing that this even got made, based on the progressive nature of media

Movies take you places you may never go. Movies show you things you may otherwise never see. Movies give you insight into people and situations you may never encounter. Movies can take you to the ocean's depths and the outer limits of the galaxy and beyond. Movies can make
you laugh, cry, feel frightened and even mesmerized.......and I could go on. In the case of "The Wire", it's an elongated movie made for tv but
nevertheless a movie. This was one of the best of it's kind ever produced, directed, written and acted and was only sorry that it had to end. I've watched this series three times since it's inception and may look forward in the future to watch it again, it was that great. The only other series I have felt this way about is "Deadwood." The only negative to either program was the language which may offend more sensitive ears. Regardless of that aspect I highly recommend this series to other like minds.

After finishing this series (seasons 1-5), I'm just stunned at the level of acting, writing and (unfortunately), the mirroring of current events 10 years after it was filmed. Tough to watch, almost heartbreaking at times ... I can't stop thinking about Duquan "Dukie" Weems in season 5.  My brother told me about "the best show he has ever seen" about 10 years ago. After watching the first season, I though that the WIRE is good, even great at timesbut not amazing; that was 10 years ago and both the times and we Americans have changed. Let season 1  sink in over some time and have patience since it builds up slowly. After re-discovering this series this year, you may feel as I have; catharsis, questioning the "Good guys versus Bad guys" over-simplifications, and quite frankly - asking what does "criminal justice" actually mean today ? No regrets about the time and mental energy needed to experience THE WIRE, it ranks among the best art in modern memory.

Although this series has been off the air for a few years, the stories it tells about Baltimore seem to be ripped from current headlines about the aftermath of the death of Freddie Gray. Each of the show's five seasons focuses on some aspect of life in the Charm City -- drug crime, unions and the waterfront, the schools, local media, etc. -- with the police and criminal justice system as the common thread connecting it all. Those who spout simplistic solutions and slogans to address the issues facing the city should be required to watch this amazing series. They'll learn that the problems -- like the characters on the show -- are complex, multi-faceted and heartbreakingly human.

The characters have tremendous depth, the acting is excellent, the story is well written and has constant twists and turns.  My wife and I were depressed when the season was over.  The ending was great, but we just wanted it to go on and on.

It is difficult to know what to say about The Wire in as much as that it is like no crime show I've ever seen. For example, what it is not is a Law and Order, a pseudo realistic show that is really another cop story designed to make the American public feel secure in the knowledge that bad things do happen but in the end all will be well, perhaps with uncomfortable complications, but never the less. we're safe. All of the CSI nonsense does essentially the same thing. It's Sherlock Holmes on steroids, who by the way did the same thing for the English reading public in bygone times. Don't worry, superior humans will get the bad guys. The Wire has none of this. There is nothing reassuring about this show and it can be downright depressing at times, mainly because we sense the truth behind the story, that there are things going on in the underbelly of the American Dream that will not change and cannot be changed by Dick Tracy showing up in his white fedora. I can't say enough about the acting, where did they find these wonderful actors who seem so natural? And the writing is as true as true has ever been conveyed on any screen. This deserves more than 5 stars and I will make a point of watching it all over again sometime in the not so distant future.

One of the biggest complaints about The Wire presented in an HD format is that the original look and feel of the show is lost due to image cropping at the top and bottom of the screen to make the originally square image fit on a widescreen TV.

I'm a stickler for that sort of thing. And I watched The Wire on HBO when it came out in it's original format. And I didn't even notice the difference. The show transforms to a 16:9 ratio very well without impacting the artistic quality of the series.

So don't hesitate to watch The Wire presented on Amazon in a widescreen format. The quality is great and you'll enjoy the show just as much (or more) than you did the first time you watched it.

Season five should peak your interest because it tells the future.  Who knew that the action in 2008 would fit the scenario now in 2015?  Recently, one of our most respected newscasters was removed from his job for fabricating a news story.  Music producers as well as singers, and authors on respected TV shows (Oprah) have been called out, ruined, or made to pay millions for their doings. We know the print medium is dying, so anything exciting seems to go.  But newscasters are supposed to be truth-tellers about what's happening in the world.  Unfortunately, season five shows us what a journalist seeking fame and fortune will sink to.  This guy blatantly creates news stories about the homeless, not realizing that the police (McNulty, who actually pretends to be homeless and talking to the reporter on the phone), as well as the actual editor of the Baltimore Sun, Mr. Haynes, are both on to him.  But what is the result of the lie?  No one listens, and the reporter gets  the Pulitzer.

Detective McNulty, Councilman Carcetti,as well as the unethical journalist all want to take on The Homeless as a cause.  But everybody does it, including academicians writing papers, etc., but they're still with us, and we see more and more of them coming out of wars.  So, what changes?  The police department doesn't change, although today people are looking at it more;  the drug culture flourishes in the hole and in the suburbs: homelessness abounds;  and The Wire asks the question:  Does anybody really care?  And they do it beautifully.

Im from Baltimore and know many of the facts  and areas they used in this series, but this season was the worse. Each season dealt with corruption in each section . The streets , the waterfront  and  Unions , Politics , the schools and last the newspaper . I didn't like any of the Reporters and the Sun  was once a very good paper too bad it didn't go back some to show us when newspapers before the internet was a good source of news , but in my time they cut the Evening Sun an then cut all the good Writers to now its trash . The only good thing about the Baltimore Sun nowadays is on Sundays with coupons ! Also they lost they edge on the street, Season 4 was quite good , it shown why Urban Kids are what they are ( unless your from Baltimore or any big city you'll understand ) . Also that Mayor is based on the real Mayor at the time Martin O'Malley who indeed succeed being a Governor ( and a very bad one at that and is now running for President ) , O'Malley hated this  show because it shown Him as He was .Though many events in this series was based on true stories ( not sure about the entire waterfront story) and names were changed, but there was a real Omar .This season was weak , though was disappointed at the end with some characters direction of what happened to them , but anyone who lives in a big city knows there's out there an  many Marlos. Too bad the series didn't continue , when  corruption within the prisons was exposed and the Police force itself . 5 stars for the first 4 seasons an only 2 for this season.

The last season of the Wire was so exciting.  It wrapped up several loose ends and answered a bunch of questions.  I really wish that it wasn't the end.  I have grown attached to these characters and want more.  To me the Wire is one of the best series on tv.  Coming in right up there with Southland.  I loved every heart stopping minute.  The last words of Snoop right before she knows she is going die is a good example of the way the writers think.  "How's my hair look?"  The reply was even creepier from Michael- "You look good, girl" right before he blows her away.  Just indicative of the quality of the show.

This show is one of the most honest and well-acted pieces of art that ever was on television. It still holds power today, even years after its production. The acting and lines are brilliant, the character building in depth, and the story is a truthful and thoughtful reflection on the corruption within the government, police department and media that is still very present today. It shows how good guys become bad guys and bad guys become good guys. It is one of the only shows I've watched to truly show the connection of corruption that is pervasive at all levels in society instead of just pointing fingers at easy targets.
